lesson.name: Lesson 6.4 Teacher Guide: Greatest Common Factor and Factor by Grouping

page.title: 6.4.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative


This lesson provides students an introduction to factoring expressions and polynomials. Students will master finding the greatest common factor (GCF) of two or more expressions by factoring the expressions into their prime factors and finding all their common factors. Finding the GCF of expressions is an essential tool used in factoring. Factoring the GCF from a polynomial is often the first step in factoring. It is important to simplify in this way before trying other ways to factor polynomials.

Students will learn to factor a polynomial by grouping in this lesson. They will use the “reverse” of the Distributive Property, and more complicated ways of factoring by grouping will be taught in later lessons. Finally, students will start to recognize when a polynomial is prime and cannot be factored any further.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Factor an expression into all of its prime factors.
  • Find the GCF of two or more expressions by factoring each expression into its prime factors and multiplying all of the common factors shared by each expression.
  • Factor the greatest common factor from a polynomial by using the “reverse” of the Distributive Property.
  • Use a grouping method to factor a polynomial when the terms of that polynomial do not share a common factor.
  • Recognize when a polynomial cannot be factored using grouping.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Find the greatest common factor of two or more expressions.
  • Factor the greatest common factor from a polynomial.
  • Factor by grouping.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)


TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A10(D) rewrite polynomial expressions of degree one and degree two in equivalent forms using the distributive property;


A10(E) factor, if possible, trinomials with real factors in the form \(ax^2 + bx + c\), including perfect square trinomials of degree two; and


A10(F) decide if a binomial can be written as the difference of two squares and, if possible, use the structure of a difference of two squares to rewrite the binomial.

Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.



Foundational: Lesson provides foundational content necessary for students to be able to perform this TEKS in later lessons.


Foundational: Lesson provides foundational content necessary for students to be able to perform this TEKS in later lessons.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 6.4.1: Finding Factors
  • 6.4.2: Finding the GCF of Two or More Expressions
    • 6.4.2: Self Check
    • 6.4.2: Additional Resources
  • 6.4.3: Factoring the GCF from Polynomials
    • 6.4.3: Self Check
    • 6.4.3: Additional Resources
  • 6.4.4: Factoring Polynomials by Grouping
    • 6.4.4: Self Check
    • 6.4.4: Additional Resources
  • 6.4.5: Can You Factor the Polynomial?

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 6.4.6: Practice.

Required Materials

  • Paper and pencil

Required Preparation

  • For Activity 6.4.2, prepare sheets of paper with the expressions \(120m^3n^2p^4\) and \(80m^2ns^4\) written separately on individual pieces. Prepare a set of these expressions for every pair of students in your class.

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson. Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson:

Previous Vocabulary

New Vocabulary
  • factoring
  • greatest common factor

Support for Building Character

Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their judgment.

Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

  • How Did You Do?
  • Through the Eyes of a Child

You can find other tips located here in the Playbook on Judgment from Character Lab.

page.title: 6.4.1: Finding Factors
page.contents:
Warm Up (5 minutes)


This warm-up activity builds and refreshes skills that are needed to factor polynomials later in the lesson. Students will split a number until all of its factors are prime numbers. They will write exponents in expanded form as repeated multiplication expressions, such as writing \(x^3\) as \(x \cdot x \cdot x\).

Students will find all of the factors in a monomial. They will also find all the common factors between two different expressions. These skills are building blocks for finding the greatest common factor (GCF) of two or more expressions in later lessons.

Launch

To help with key concepts in the activity, ask students to define a prime number. If there is any confusion, introduce the definition here:

  • A prime number is a number greater than 1 whose only factors are 1 and the number itself. Examples of prime numbers are: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13 . . .

Remind students that the least common multiple (LCM) of two numbers is the smallest number that is a multiple of both numbers.

Allow time for students to answer the questions in the activity.

Student Activity

Finding the factors of a number, monomial, or polynomial is an important step used in the activities of this lesson.


  1. Factor 56 into prime numbers to find all of its factors.

ANSWER: \(7 \cdot 2\cdot 2\cdot 2\)

  1. Find all of the factors of \(42m^3y^2\).

ANSWER: \(7\cdot 2\cdot 3\cdot m\cdot m\cdot m\cdot y\cdot y\)

  1. Find all of the common factors between \(6n^2p^2\) and \(9ns^2\).

ANSWER: 3 and \(n\)

  1. Find the least common multiple (LCM) of \(3x^2\) and \(8x^4\).

ANSWER: \(24x^4\)


Activity Synthesis

Emphasize the following key points from the lesson:

  • A prime number is a number greater than 1 whose only factors are 1 and the number itself.
  • Any expression can be factored until it is prime or each of its factors is prime.
  • The factors of an expression can be written out in expanded form as repeated multiplication. This format is useful for finding common factors between two different expressions.

page.title: 6.4.2: Finding the GCF of Two or More Expressions
page.contents:
Activity (25 minutes)

This activity uses several different methods to introduce students to finding the greatest common factor (GCF) of two or more expressions. Students will factor each expression into all of its prime factors. They will compare these lists of factors to determine which ones they all have in common. By multiplying these common factors together, students will find their GCF.

Launch

Start the lesson by introducing vocabulary that will be helpful:

factoring an expression:

  • Factoring is splitting a product into its prime factors. If these factors are multiplied together, the result will be the original product.

greatest common factor:

  • The greatest common factor (GCF) of two or more expressions is the largest expression that is a factor of all the expressions.

Students will become more familiar with these terms as the lesson progresses.

Prepare sheets of paper with the expressions \(120m^3n^2p^4\) and \(80m^2ns^4\) written separately on individual pieces. Prepare a set of these expressions for every pair of students in your class.

Arrange the students into pairs for the activity. Hand out one expression, \(120m^3n^2p^4\), to one student of the pair and the other expression, \(80m^2ns^4\), to the other student. Instruct the students not to share their expression with anyone. Read the instructions for the activity as a class and address any confusion around the rules. Allow 5 minutes for the pairs to complete the activity. After the activity is complete, share the expressions that were used and their GCF, \(40m^2n\).

Spend 5 minutes reviewing the next example as a class. Walk the students through each step, stopping to address any concerns. Then allow the remainder of the time for students to complete the exercises individually. With any additional time, answer any questions students may have about finding the GCF of these expressions.

Student Activity

For the first part of the activity, you will work with a partner. Your teacher will hand out two pieces of paper, one to each of you. It is important for the activity that you do not show your partner your paper.

  1. When you receive your paper, look at your expression. Write down all of the factors in your expression.

    2. If your expression was \(100x^3y^2\), you would write down \(2 \cdot 2 \cdot 5 \cdot 5 \cdot x \cdot x \cdot x \cdot y \cdot y\). Do not share these factors with your partner yet.

  1. When you and your partner have finished finding the factors of your expression, you will try to determine the GCF of these two terms without actually knowing the other’s expression!

    Take turns with your partner sharing one factor and the quantity of that factor. For example, you could say, “My expression has two factors that are 5” or “My expression has three factors that are \(x\).” Write down the factors your partner has shared with you.

  1. Once you and your partner have finished taking turns sharing factors, you should know all of the factors in your partner’s expression. Using this information, determine your partner’s expression and find the GCF of these two expressions.

    Once you have found the GCF, compare your answer with your partner’s. Did you have the same answer?

Write the GCF that you found.

ANSWER:
Expression A: \(120m^3n^2p^4\)

Factors of Expression A: \(2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot m \cdot m \cdot m \cdot n \cdot n \cdot p \cdot p \cdot p \cdot p\)

Expression B: \(80m^2ns^4\)

Factors of Expression B: \(2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 5 \cdot m \cdot m \cdot n \cdot s \cdot s \cdot s \cdot s\)

GCF: \(2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 5 \cdot m \cdot m \cdot n = 40m^2n\)

Now, let’s look at an of example finding the GCF of two expressions as a class:

  1. \(18g^4h^2, 63g^3h^3\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

ANSWER:

Step 1
Factor each coefficient into primes. Write all variables with exponents in expanded form.
\(18g^4h^2 = 3 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot g \cdot g \cdot g \cdot g \cdot h \cdot h\)

\(63g^3h^3 = 3 \cdot 3 \cdot 7 \cdot g \cdot g \cdot g \cdot h \cdot h \cdot h\)

Step 2
List all factors, matching common factors in a column. In each column, circle the common factors.

Step 3
Bring down the common factors that all expressions share.
GCF = \(3 \cdot 3 \cdot g \cdot g \cdot g \cdot h \cdot h\)

Step 4
Multiply the factors.
GCF = \(9g^3h^2\)

Work individually on the next part of the activity.

Find the greatest common factor of each of the following sets of expressions.

  1. \(10p^3q, 12pq^2\)

ANSWER: \(2pq\)

  1. \(8a^2b^3, 10ab^2\)

ANSWER: \(2ab^2\)

  1. \(10a^3, 12a^2, 14a\)

ANSWER: \(2a\)

  1. \(35x^3y^2, 10x4y, 5x^5y^3\)

ANSWER: \(5x^3y\)

Anticipated Misconceptions

As students play the game with their partner, it is important that, in the first step, they correctly factor their original expression into its prime factors. Monitor for those who do not completely factor each expression into all of its prime factors. Challenge students to analyze each factor they have found and be sure that each factor cannot be factored any further.

Activity Synthesis

Ask students how they were able to determine their partner’s expression in the game without actually knowing what it was. (By multiplying all of the factors their partner provided, they could find their partner’s expression.)

Ask a student to explain in their own words how to find the GCF of two different expressions. Use the list below to help the student as needed:

  • Step 1. Factor each coefficient into primes. Write all variables with exponents in expanded form.
  • Step 2. List all factors, matching common factors in a column. In each column, circle the common factors.
  • Step 3. Bring down the common factors that all expressions share.
  • Step 4. Multiply the factors.

6.4.2: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

Find the greatest common factor of \(25m^4, 35m^3, 20m^2\).

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(10m^2\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Each expression does not share the factor 2, so the GCF cannot include 10. The answer is \(5m^2\).

\(5m\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Each expression has at least two factors of \(m\), so the GCF will have \(m^2\). The answer is \(5m^2\).

\(5m^2\)

That’s correct! Check yourself: All of these expressions share the factors \(5 \cdot m \cdot m\).

\(10m\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Each expression does not share the factor 2, so the GCF cannot include 10. Each expression has at least two factors of \(m\), so the GCF will have \(m^2\). The answer is \(5m^2\).

6.4.2: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Finding the GCF of Two or More Expressions

Earlier, we multiplied factors together to get a product. Now, we will reverse this process; we will start with a product and then break it down into its factors. Splitting a product into factors is called factoring.

Now we will factor expressions and find the greatest common factor of two or more expressions.

GREATEST COMMON FACTOR

The greatest common factor (GCF) of two or more expressions is the largest expression that is a factor of all the expressions.


We will summarize the steps we use to find the greatest common factor.

How to find the greatest common factor (GCF) of two expressions:

Step 1
Factor each coefficient into primes. Write all variables with exponents in expanded form.

Step 2
List all factors, matching common factors in a column. In each column, circle the common factors.

Step 3
Bring down the common factors that all expressions share.

Step 4
Multiply the factors.

The following example will show the steps to find the greatest common factor of three expressions.

EXAMPLE

Find the greatest common factor of \(21x^3, 9x^2, 15x\).

Step 1
Factor each coefficient into primes and write the variables with exponents in expanded form.

Step 2
Circle the common factors in each column.

Step 3
Bring down the common factors.

Step 4
Multiply the factors.
GFC = \(3x\)

The GCF of \(21x^3\), \(9x^2\), and \(15x\) is \(3x\).

Try It: Finding the GCF of Two or More Expressions

Find the greatest common factor of \(14x^3, 105x, 70x^2\).

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to find the GCF of multiple expressions.

The GCF of these expressions is \(7x\).

page.title: 6.4.3: Factoring the GCF from Polynomials
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity takes the steps students have learned so far, factoring expressions and finding their GCF, and adds the step of factoring the GCF from the polynomial.

Having a mastery of the Distributive Property is crucial for understanding how it can be “reversed” to factor the GCF out of each expression in a polynomial.

Launch

Start the lesson by reviewing the Distributive Property with students.

DISTRIBUTIVE PROPERTY

If \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) are real numbers, then

\(\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;a(b + c) = ab + ac\) and \(ab + ac = a(b + c)\)

The form on the left is used to multiply. The form on the right is used to factor.


Emphasize that the equation on the left is often used to distribute a value into a group of expressions. The equation on the right can be thought of as the Distributive Property “in reverse” and will be very useful in factoring expressions.

Use 7–8 minutes to review the example at the start of the activity. As students have already performed many of the steps for factoring the values and finding the GCF, ask them to explain the first steps as far as they can. Guide them through any missing steps.

Finally, ask students to complete questions 1–8 individually. If needed, solve the first one together as a class.

Student Activity

To factor a GCF from a polynomial and represent it in factored form, we must first find the GCF.

Let’s look at an example: \(7z^5 − 21sz^3\).

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

SOLUTION:

Step 1
Find the GCF of the terms in the polynomial:

The GCF of the terms is \(7z^3\).

Step 2
Apply the Distributive Property “in reverse” to factor out the GCF from each term.

\(7z^5 − 21sz^3 = {\style{color:red}7} {\style{color:red}z} ^ {\style{color:red}3} \cdot z^2 − {\style{color:red}7} {\style{color:red}z} ^ {\style{color:red}3} \cdot 3s\)

\(\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;= 7z^3(z^2 − 3s)\)

The factored form is \(7z^3(z^2 − 3s)\).

Work individually on the following problems.

Factor the GCF from each polynomial. Remember that if the leading coefficient is negative, then the GCF will be negative.

  1. \(5x^3 − 25x^2\)

ANSWER: \(5x^2(x − 5)\)

  1. \(8x^3y − 10x^2y^2 + 12xy^3\)

ANSWER: \(2xy(4x^2 − 5xy + 6y^2)\)

  1. \(−5y^3 + 35y^2 − 15y\)

ANSWER: \(−5y(y^2 − 7y + 3)\)

  1. \(15x^3y − 3x^2y^2 + 6xy^3\)

ANSWER: \(3xy(5x^2 − xy + 2y^2)\)

  1. \(−4p^3q − 12p^2q^2 + 16pq^2\)

ANSWER: \(−4pq(p^2 + 3pq − 4q)\)

  1. \(5x(x + 1) + 3(x + 1)\)

ANSWER: \((x + 1)(5x + 3)\)

  1. \(3b(b − 2) − 13(b − 2)\)

ANSWER: \((b − 2)(3b − 13)\)

  1. \(6m(m − 5) − 7(m − 5)\)

ANSWER: \((m − 5)(6m − 7)\)

Anticipated Misconceptions

Students may run into trouble in the activity if they are unable to find the correct GCF of the expressions in the polynomial. Students who do not list each prime factor for each expression may not completely factor those expressions. This will lead to finding a common factor that is not the greatest common factor. After factoring out their common factor, the polynomial will not be completely factored. Emphasize that listing the prime factors for each expression is a very important step in the process.

Activity Synthesis

Ask a student to describe each step in factoring a GCF from a polynomial. Use the list below to help the student as needed:

  • Step 1: Find the GCF of all the terms in the polynomial.
  • Step 2: Rewrite each term as a product using the GCF.
  • Step 3: Use the “reverse” of the Distributive Property to factor the expression.
  • Step 4: Check your answer by multiplying the factors together.

6.4.3: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.


QUESTION:

Factor: \(8a^3b + 2a^2b^2 − 6ab^3\).

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(−2ab(4a^2 + ab − 3b^2)\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: You should not have factored out a negative sign in the GCF. The correct answer is \(2ab(4a^2 + ab − 3b^2)\).

\(ab(8a^2 + 2ab − 6b^2)\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The GCF you found is missing the factor 2. The correct answer is \(2ab(4a^2 + ab − 3b^2)\).

\(2b(4a^3 + a^2b − 3ab^2)\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The GCF you found is missing the factor \(a\). The correct answer is \(2ab(4a^2 + ab − 3b^2)\).

\(2ab(4a^2 + ab − 3b^2)\)

That’s correct! Check yourself: Multiply \((2ab)(4a^2 + ab − 3b^2)\) to see if it equals \(8a^3b + 2a^2b^2 − 6ab^3\). Since it does, the answer is correct.

6.4.3: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Factoring the GCF from Polynomials

It is sometimes useful to represent a number as a product of factors, for example, 12 as \(2 \cdot 6\) or \(3 \cdot 4\). In algebra, it can also be useful to represent a polynomial in factored form. We will start with a product, such as \(3x^2+15x\), and end with its factors, \(3x(x + 5)\). To do this, we apply the Distributive Property “in reverse.” We state the Distributive Property here just as you saw it in earlier chapters and “in reverse.”

DISTRIBUTIVE PROPERTY

If \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) are real numbers, then

\(\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;a(b + c) = ab + ac\) and \(ab + ac = a(b + c)\)

The form on the left is used to multiply. The form on the right is used to factor.


So how do you use the Distributive Property to factor a polynomial? You just find the GCF of all the terms and write the polynomial as a product!

EXAMPLE 1

Factor: \(8m^3-12m^2n+20mn^2\).

How to factor the greatest common factor from a polynomial:

Step 1
Find the GCF of all the terms of the polynomial. For this problem, find the GCF of \(8m^3\), \(12m^2n\), and \(20mn^2\).

Step 2
Rewrite each term as a product using the GCF. In this case, rewrite \(8m^3\), \(12m^2n\), and \(20mn^2\) as products of their GCF, \(4m\).

  • \(8m^3 = {\style{color:red}4} {\style{color:red}m} \cdot 2m^2\)
  • \(12m^2n = {\style{color:red}4} {\style{color:red}m} \cdot 3mn\)
  • \(20mn^2 = {\style{color:red}4} {\style{color:red}m} \cdot 5n^2\)

\(8m^3-12m^2n+20mn^2\)
\({\style{color:red}4} {\style{color:red}m} \cdot 2m^2 - {\style{color:red}4} {\style{color:red}m} \cdot 3mn + {\style{color:red}4} {\style{color:red}m} \cdot 5n^2\)

Step 3
Use the “reverse” Distributive Property to factor the expression.

\(4m(2m^2-3mn+5n^2)\)

Step 4
Check by multiplying the factors.

\(4m(2m^2-3mn+5n^2)\)
\(4m \cdot 2m^2 - 4m \cdot 3mn + 4m \cdot 5n^2\)
\(8m^3-12m^2n+20mn^2\)

When the leading coefficient is negative, we factor the negative out as part of the GCF.

EXAMPLE 2

Factor: \(−4a^3 + 36a^2 − 8a\).

The leading coefficient is negative, so the GCF will be negative.

Step 1
Rewrite each term using the GCF, \(−4a\).
\( {\style{color:red}-} {\style{color:red}4} {\style{color:red}a} \cdot a^2 − {\style{color:red}(} {\style{color:red}-} {\style{color:red}4} {\style{color:red}a} {\style{color:red})} \cdot 9a + {\style{color:red}(}{\style{color:red}-} {\style{color:red}4} {\style{color:red}a} {\style{color:red})} \cdot 2\)

Step 2
Factor the GCF.
\(−4a(a^2 − 9a + 2)\)

Step 3
Check.
\(−4a(a^2 − 9a + 2)\)
\(−4a \cdot a^2 − (−4a) \cdot 9a + (−4a) \cdot 2\)
\(−4a^3 + 36a^2 − 8a\)

So far, our greatest common factors have been monomials. In the next example, the greatest common factor is a binomial.

EXAMPLE 3

Factor: \(3y {\style{color:red}(} {\style{color:red}y} \;{\style{color:red}+}\;     {\style{color:red}7} {\style{color:red})} − 4{\style{color:red}(} {\style{color:red}y}\;     {\style{color:red}+} \;{\style{color:red}7} {\style{color:red})}\).

The GCF is the binomial \(y + 7\).

\(3y(y + 7) − 4(y + 7)\).

Step 1
Factor the GCF, \((y + 7)\).
\((y + 7)(3y − 4)\)

Step 2
Check on your own by multiplying.


Try It: Factoring the GCF from Polynomials

Factor.

  1. \(9xy^2 + 6x^2y^2 + 21y^3\)
  1. \(−4b^3 + 16b^2 − 8b\)
  1. \(4m(m + 3) − 7(m + 3)\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to factor the GCF from polynomials.

  1. \(3y^2(3x + 2x^2 + 7y)\)
  1. \(−4b(b^2 − 4b + 2)\)
  1. \((m + 3)(4m − 7)\)

page.title: 6.4.4: Factoring Polynomials by Grouping
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity prompts students to find a way to factor a polynomial in which there is not a common factor in all of the terms of the polynomial. By grouping different parts of the polynomial together, they can find a GCF for each individual part. If the polynomial can be factored, a common factor will emerge from both parts.

Launch

Start the lesson by explaining that some polynomials will not have a common factor in all of their terms. Use the polynomial in the first example to illustrate this point, \(ms − 4m + 7s − 28\). Challenge students to find any common factor in all the terms of the polynomial.

Explain that polynomials can be split into smaller parts, and we can start factoring there. Review the example step by step. Check for understanding after each step.

Finally, ask students to complete questions 1–8 individually. If needed, solve the first one together as a class.

Student Activity

If there is no common term in all of the terms of a polynomial, it may be possible to factor by grouping. To do this, separate the polynomial into two parts with two terms in each part. Then look for the GCF in each part. If the polynomial can be factored, you will find that a common factor emerges from both parts.

Let’s look at an example. Factor the following polynomial.

\(ms − 4m + 7s − 28\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

SOLUTION:

Step 1
Group terms with common factors.
Is there a GCF of all four terms? No, so let’s separate the first two terms from the second two.
\(ms − 4m + 7s − 28\)

Step 2
Factor out the common factor in each group.
Factor the GCF from the first two terms. Factor the GCF from the second two terms.
\(m(s − 4) + 7s − 28\)
\(m(s − 4) + 7(s − 4)\)

Step 3
Factor the common factor from the expression.
Notice that each term has a common factor of \((s − 4)\). Factor out the common factor.
\(m {\style{color:red}(} {\style{color:red}s} \;{\style{color:red}-}\;     {\style{color:red}4} {\style{color:red})} + 7{\style{color:red}(} {\style{color:red}s}\;     {\style{color:red}-}\;     {\style{color:red}4} {\style{color:red})}\)
\((s − 4)(m + 7)\)

Step 4
Check.
Multiply \((s − 4)(m + 7)\). Is the product the original expression?
\((s − 4)(m + 7)\)
\(ms +7s − 4m − 28\)
\(ms − 4m + 7s − 28\) \({\style{color:red}✓}\)

Work on the following exercises individually.

Factor by grouping:

  1. \(xy + 7y + 8x + 56\)

ANSWER: \((x + 7)(y + 8)\)

  1. \(x^2 + 2x − 5x − 10\)

ANSWER: \((x − 5)(x + 2)\)

  1. \(20x^2 − 16x − 15x + 12\)

ANSWER: \((5x − 4)(4x − 3)\)

  1. \(x^2 + 4x − 7x − 28\)

ANSWER: \((x + 4)(x − 7)\)

  1. \(2x^2 − 14x − 5x + 35\)

ANSWER: \((x − 7)(2x − 5)\)

  1. \(xy − 6x − 4y + 24\)

ANSWER: \((y − 6)(x − 4)\)

  1. \(9x^2 + 12x − 15x − 20\)

ANSWER: \((3x − 5)(3x + 4)\)

  1. \(xy − 9x + 2y − 18\)

ANSWER: \((x + 2)(y − 9)\)

Anticipated Misconceptions

Emphasize to students that if the first two terms do not have a common factor, that does not guarantee that the polynomial cannot be factored by grouping. They should still look for a GCF in the last two terms. It might also be possible to rearrange the terms so that the polynomial can be factored by grouping. Students should check all possibilities before determining that a polynomial is prime.

Activity Synthesis

Ask students to write down the steps used when factoring by grouping. Use the list below to guide students as needed:

Step 1
Group terms with common factors.

Step 2
Factor out the common factor in each group.

Step 3
Factor out the common factor from the expression.

Step 4
Check your answer by multiplying the factors together.

Ask students how many unique ways there are to group a polynomial with four terms into two pairs of terms.

There are 3 ways:

  • Grouping the first two terms together
  • Grouping the first and third terms together
  • Grouping the first and last terms together

Video: Factoring by Grouping

Watch the following video to learn more about how to factor by grouping.



6.4.4: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

Factor by grouping: \(42m^2 − 18m − 35m + 15\).

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\((14m − 3)(3m − 5)\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Factor out \(6m\) from the first two terms and −5 from the second two terms. The correct answer is \((7m − 3)(6m − 5)\).

\((7m − 3)(6m − 5)\)

That’s correct! Check yourself: Multiply \((7m − 3)(6m − 5)\) to see if it is equal to \(42m^2 − 18m − 35m + 15\).

\((7m + 3)(6m + 5)\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Check the signs of each factor. Factor out \(6m\) from the first two terms and −5 from the second two terms. The correct answer is \((7m − 3)(6m − 5)\).

\((7m − 5)(6m − 3)\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Factor out \(6m\) from the first two terms and −5 from the second two terms. Be careful to match the second term of each binomial with the correct first term. The correct answer is \((7m − 3)(6m − 5)\).

6.4.4: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Factoring Polynomials by Grouping

Sometimes there is no common factor of all the terms of a polynomial. When there are four terms, we separate the polynomial into two parts with two terms in each part. Then look for the GCF in each part. If the polynomial can be factored, you will find that a common factor emerges from both parts. Not all polynomials can be factored. Just like some numbers are prime, some polynomials are prime.

EXAMPLE 1

Factor by grouping: \(xy + 3y + 2x + 6\).

Step 1
Group terms with common factors.
Is there a greatest common factor of all four terms?
\(xy + 3y + 2x + 6\)
No, so let’s separate the first two terms from the second two.

Step 2
Factor out the common factor in each group.
Factor the GCF from the first two terms.

Factor the GCF from the second two terms.
\(y(x + 3) + 2(x + 3)\)

Step 3
Factor the common factor from the expression.
Notice that each term has a common factor of \((x+3)\).
\(y {\style{color:red}(} {\style{color:red}x} \;{\style{color:red}+}\;     {\style{color:red}3} {\style{color:red})} + 2 {\style{color:red}(} {\style{color:red}x}\;     {\style{color:red}+}\;     {\style{color:red}3} {\style{color:red})} \)
Factor out the common factor.
\((x + 3)(y + 2)\)

Step 4
Check.
Multiply \((x + 3)(y + 2)\). Is the product the original expression?
\((x + 3)(y + 2)\)
\(xy + 2x + 3y + 6\)
\(xy + 3y + 2x + 6 \checkmark\)

How to factor by grouping:

Step 1
Group terms with common factors.

Step 2
Factor out the common factor in each group.

Step 3
Factor the common factor from the expression.

Step 4
Check by multiplying the factors.

EXAMPLE 2

Factor by grouping: \(x^2 + 3x − 2x − 6\).

Step 1
There is no GCF in all four terms.
\(x^2 + 3x − 2x − 6\)

Step 2
Separate into two parts.
\(x^2 + 3x \;\;\;\;\;\;\; − 2x − 6\)

Step 3
Factor the GCF from both parts. Be careful with the signs when factoring the GCF from the last two terms.
\(x(x + 3) − 2(x + 3)\)

Step 4
Factor out the common factor.
\((x + 3)(x − 2)\)

Step 5
Check on your own by multiplying.

Try It: Factoring Polynomials by Grouping

Factor by grouping:

  1. \(xy + 8y + 3x + 24\)

  1. \(6x^2 − 3x − 4x + 2\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to factor polynomials by grouping.

  1. Step 1
    There is no GCF in all four terms.
    \(xy + 8y + 3x + 24\)

    Step 2
    Separate into two parts.
    \(xy + 8y\;\;\;\;\;\;\;+ 3x + 24\)

    Step 3
    Factor the GCF from both parts.
    \(y(x + 8) + 3(x + 8)\)

    Step 4
    Factor out the common factor.
    \((x + 8)(y + 3)\)

    Step 5
    Check on your own by multiplying.

  1. Step 1
    There is no GCF in all four terms.
    \(6x^2 − 3x − 4x + 2\)

    Step 2
    Separate into two parts.
    \(6x^2 − 3x\;\;\;\;\;\;\;− 4x + 2\)

    Step 3
    Factor the GCF from both parts.
    \(3x(2x − 1) − 2(2x − 1)\)

    Step 4
    Factor out the common factor.
    \((2x − 1)(3x − 2)\)

    Step 5
    Check on your own by multiplying.

page.title: 6.4.5: Can You Factor the Polynomial?
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)


Student Activity

  1. Which of these polynomials has a greatest common factor of 1?
  • \(10q^2 + 14q + 20\)
  • \(12x^3 − 2x\)
  • \(12x^3y − 7g^8h^3 + 11s^2\)
  • \(−2x − 4\)

ANSWER:  \(12x^3y − 7g^8h^3 + 11s^2\)

Determine if the expression can be factored by grouping. If it can, factor the expression. If not, answer “prime.”

  1. \(cd + 6c + 4d + 24\)

ANSWER: \((d + 6)(c + 4)\)

  1. \(x^2 − y + 4w − 3\)

ANSWER: prime

page.title: 6.4.6: Practice
page.contents:
Students will complete the following questions to practice the skills they have learned in this lesson.

For questions 1–3, find the GCF of each set of expressions.

  1. \(12m^2n^3, 30m^5n^3\)
    • \(6m^3n^3\)
    • \(3m^2n^3\)
    • \(2m^5n^3\)
    • \(6m^2n^3\)

ANSWER: \(6m^2n^3\)

  1. \(28x^2y^4,42x^4y^4\)
    • \(7x^4y^4\)
    • \(14x^2y^4\)
    • \(14x^4y^4\)
    • \(7x^2y^4\)

ANSWER: \(14x^2y^4\)

  1. \(27p^2q^3,45p^3q^4,9p^4q^3\)
    • \(9pq^3\)
    • \(27p^2q^3\)
    • \(9p^2q^3\)
    • \(9p^3q^3\)

ANSWER: \(9p^2q^3\)

For questions 4–6, factor the expression.

  1. \(15x^3y − 3x^2y^2 + 6xy^3\)
    • \(3xy(5x^2 − xy + 2y^2)\)
    • \(3xy^2(5x^2 − x + 2y)\)
    • \(xy(15x^2 − 3xy + 6y^2)\)
    • \(3x^2y(5x − y + 2y^2)\)

ANSWER: \(3xy(5x^2−xy+2y^2)\)

  1. \(−7a^3 + 21a^2 − 14a\)
    • \(−7(a^2 − 3a + 2)\)
    • \(7a(a^2 − 3a + 2)\)
    • \(−7a^2(a − 1)\)
    • \(−7a(a^2 − 3a + 2)\)

ANSWER: \(−7a(a^2 − 3a + 2)\)

  1. \(8n(n − 4) + 5(n − 4)\)
    • \((n + 4)(8n + 5)\)
    • \((n − 4)(8n − 5)\)
    • \((n − 4)(8n + 5)\)
    • \((8n − 4)(n + 5)\)

ANSWER: \((n − 4)(8n + 5)\)

For questions 7–10, factor by grouping.

  1. \(u^2 − u + 6u − 6\)
    • \((u + 1)(u + 6)\)
    • \((u − 1)(u − 6)\)
    • \((u + 1)(u − 6)\)
    • \((u − 1)(u + 6)\)

ANSWER: \((u − 1)(u + 6)\)

  1. \(16q^2 + 20q − 28q − 35\)
    • \((4q + 5)(4q + 7)\)
    • \((4q − 5)(4q + 7)\)
    • \((4q + 5)(4q − 7)\)
    • \((4q − 5)(4q − 7)\)

ANSWER: \((4q + 5)(4q − 7)\)

  1. \(r^2 − 3r − r + 3\)
    • \((r − 3)(r − 1)\)
    • \((r + 3)(r + 1)\)
    • \((r − 3)(r + 1)\)
    • \((r + 3)(r − 1)\)

ANSWER: \((r − 3)(r − 1)\)

  1. \(6y^2 + 7y + 24y + 28\)
    • \((6y + 7)(y + 4)\)
    • \((y + 7)(6y + 4)\)
    • \((6y − 7)(y − 4)\)
    • \((y + 7)(6y − 4)\)

ANSWER: \((6y + 7)(y + 4)\)

page.title: 6.4.7: Lesson Synthesis
page.contents:
Here are some key takeaways from this lesson to share with students:

  • An essential step in finding the GCF of two or more expressions is writing each of the expressions in expanded form as the multiplication of all of its prime factors.
  • To find the GCF of two or more expressions, list all the factors of each expression. Then find the common factors that are in every expression. Multiply these factors together.
  • To factor the GCF from a polynomial, first find the GCF of all of the terms in the polynomial. Then use the “reverse” of the Distributive Property to factor the GCF out of each expression in the polynomial.
  • Sometimes there is not a common factor in every term of a polynomial. However, it can still be factored using a method called grouping. The terms of the polynomial are grouped together so that a GCF can be factored from the first part and another GCF can be factored from the second part. If the polynomial can be factored further, a common factor will emerge from both parts.
